channel.title: Psychosis
channel.description:
Anyone here ever experience psychosis? I'm sure I'm not the only one. Mine happened after a night of partying when I sick with a slight fever (which I didn't know of at the time). I woke up hungover with a fever of roughly 40C. I experienced psychosis which was things such as paranoia, and things such as colours and text were sticking out for no apparent reason. No crazy hallucinations but I saw one or two things that my mom explained were never there. Anyone else?
-Holic

item.title: Psychosis
item.dc:creator: @ninja_nub ninja nub
item.description:
@ninja_nub wrote:

I’ve had it. I hear things and see things.

One time, got up from bed to use the bathroom, and then I see gray figures flash across me. And a week after I heard voices and people singing. No, it was not my neighbors

Read full topic

item.title: Psychosis
item.dc:creator: @mikkomainer Secet
item.description:
@mikkomainer wrote:

One friend of mine has been using drugs for two years now, no single sober day. About two months ago he had a major psychosis and attacked his mother, after that her mom kicked him out.

Luckily that guy was enough wise to go to hospital, mental hospital. He has been there for about two months. First he was under really strong medication, but now he is almost like normal. He might get free apartment, but rules are: No drugs or alcohol.
He can never drink or use drugs, because psychosis might come back. And if you get it twice…Well, you ain’t leaving hospital very soon…

Read full topic

item.title: Psychosis
item.dc:creator: @Holic Holic
item.description:
@Holic wrote:

[quote=“bootnecklad, post:14, topic:185033”]Most evil (no)
Anyway on this program called most evil this Swedish guy or someone made a scale from 1-20 and most of the people with ‘Psychosis’ where in the range from 11-20. The scale being the people they killed why how and what they did with them.[/quote]
Common misconception, psychosis has nothing to do with psychopathy.
Meaning psychosis shouldn’t be linked to violence as it doesn’t make you violent.

-Holic

Read full topic

item.title: Psychosis
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

You are both right. Psychosis is a state of mind, usually induced by a mental disorder (always really, depends if you class stress-induced psychosis as a disorder). Neurosis is another imbalance caused by mental illness, but one in which the individual has some belief/contact with reality.

For example, believing that your fridge is going to eat you would be a psychosis.
Avoiding fridges because you have anorexia and may be tempted by the food would be a neurosis.

Taking A-level Psychology combines elements of both.

(Did anyone catch the film reference in the post? :D)

Read full topic

item.title: Psychosis
item.dc:creator: @Holic Holic
item.description:
@Holic wrote:

Odd. That’s not what the schizophrenic society of BC has led us to believe. I know common things such as stress and sleep deprivation can lead to it, I wouldn’t figure those really have anything to do with a mental illness seeing as everyone goes through it.
I’ll look a little deeper.

-Holic

Read full topic

item.title: Psychosis
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

[quote=“Holic, post:10, topic:185033”]Any drug can induce psychosis even though lots of people believe natural drugs (weed, shrooms) don’t.
Although I’ve experienced it, it doesn’t mean I have any sort of mental illness which is also commonly thought.
My only “illnesses” are sleep apnoea and dyslexia. So lack of sleep, drinking and the fever combined did it for me.

jme: Schizophrenics experience psychosis, but like I said you don’t have to be mentally ill to experience it.
And being high as fuck doesn’t count ;). There’s a difference in the symptoms.

-Holic[/quote]

In school, we were taught that psychosis was a catagory of mental illnesses, as opposed to neurosis.

Read full topic

item.title: Psychosis
item.dc:creator: @Holic Holic
item.description:
@Holic wrote:

Any drug can induce psychosis even though lots of people believe natural drugs (weed, shrooms) don’t.
Although I’ve experienced it, it doesn’t mean I have any sort of mental illness which is also commonly thought.
My only “illnesses” are sleep apnoea and dyslexia. So lack of sleep, drinking and the fever combined did it for me.

jme: Schizophrenics experience psychosis, but like I said you don’t have to be mentally ill to experience it.
And being high as fuck doesn’t count ;). There’s a difference in the symptoms.

-Holic

Read full topic

item.title: Psychosis
item.dc:creator: @dragonfire455 dragonfire455
item.description:
@dragonfire455 wrote:

Psychosis is a generic psychiatric term for a mental state often described as involving a “loss of contact with reality.” People suffering from it are said to be psychotic.

People experiencing psychosis may report hallucinations or delusional beliefs, and may exhibit personality changes and disorganized thinking. This may be accompanied by unusual or bizarre behaviour, as well as difficulty with social interaction and impairment in carrying out the activities of daily living.

A wide variety of nervous system stressors, both organic and functional, can cause a psychotic reaction. This has led to the belief that psychosis is the ‘fever’ of mental illness—a serious but nonspecific indicator.[1][2]

However, most people have unusual and reality-distorting experiences at some point in their lives, without being impaired or even distressed by these experiences. For example, many people have experienced visions of some kind, and some have even found inspiration or religious revelation in them.[3] As a result, it has been argued that psychosis is not fundamentally separate from normal consciousness, but rather, is on a continuum with normal consciousness.[4] In this view, people who are clinically found to be psychotic, may simply be having particularly intense or distressing experiences

Read full topic
